awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Artificial Intelligence and Network Theory for Elections
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project promotes and enhances transparency in the democratic process. It accomplishes this by developing a social awareness system that can detect, understand, and predict opinion trends within a democratic society. Through the development of cutting-edge artificial intelligence (AI) techniques, the project contributes to scientific and technological knowledge by improving the prediction of election results and societal opinion trends with high accuracy. By employing machine learning, the project aims to surpass the limitations of traditional polling methods and provide a real-time predictor of election outcomes worldwide. The project will address the credibility of news on social media serving to strengthen the resilience of the population against misinformation. In addition, the project demonstrates a commitment to inclusivity by actively seeking the participation of underrepresented minorities. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to predict global elections in real-time through the integration of artificial intelligence, network theory, and big data science. By harnessing the power of advanced machine learning models and analyzing vast amounts of publicly expressed opinions on social media, the team offers accurate forecasts of election outcomes. This approach has the potential to disrupt the conventional polling industry, which faces growing uncertainties and challenges such as declining response rates and inherent biases in sampling. The research objectives entail tackling critical research and development challenges, including predicting voter turnout, effectively sampling rural areas with limited online coverage, filtering out bots and fake news sources, inferring the preferences of undecided voters, adjusting sample weights on a state-by-state basis, addressing the opinions of individuals not active on social media, and mitigating social desirability bias (where respondents conceal their intention to vote for controversial candidates). The anticipated technical results involve the development of a transformative machine learning architecture built upon Graph Neural Networks.  The framework enables optimized resource allocation and significantly improves the precision of predictions. Ultimately, the results will empower decision-makers with reliable real-time information, facilitating informed choices, and enhancing the resilience of the democratic process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Election Forecasting through AI

Kcore Analytics has developed an AI-driven election prediction platform that leverages publicly available social media data and advanced machine learning for accurate political forecasting. This project, funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF), aims to address the long-standing limitations of traditional polling, including declining response rates, sampling biases, and the inaccuracies observed in recent elections. Our approach offers an innovative, scalable, and non-intrusive method for gauging voter sentiment.

The Problem with Traditional Polling. Recent studies, including a comprehensive report by the American Association for Public Opinion Research (AAPOR), have confirmed the decreasing reliability of traditional election polling. National surveys of the 2020 U.S. presidential election were the least accurate in 40 years, while state-level polls performed even worse. These trends persisted in the 2024 U.S. election, underscoring the urgent need for a more robust alternative. Our AI-based approach seeks to fill this gap by harnessing real-time public social media data to predict political elections more accurately than conventional polling methods.

Our AI-Based Solution. Our methodology integrates multiple machine learning models, including Large Language Models (LLMs) and Graph Neural Networks (GNNs), to analyze vast amounts of social media data. Instead of relying on direct survey responses, our system classifies social media content. This approach significantly reduces response bias and enhances the predictive power of election forecasting.

Key Findings from Phase I

Through extensive testing, we confirmed that social media interactions could serve as a viable proxy for public sentiment, closely aligning with real election outcomes. Our model successfully predicted national election outcomes with a high degree of accuracy, providing robust and timely assessment of voter sentiment. Notably, our approach demonstrated strong performance in the 2024 U.S. presidential election, where it captured shifts in voter support more effectively than conventional polling methods. This accuracy highlights the robustness of our methodology and its potential as a transformative tool in political forecasting.

One of the main challenges in using social media data for election forecasting is that social media content may not be representative of the general population. We developed demographic rescaling techniques to correct for these and other biases. By incorporating voter turnout modeling and rural/urban adjustments, we reduced the bias and improved prediction accuracy at the state level.

To test the versatility of our model, we applied it to the 2024 Indian general elections and the Fortaleza mayoral election in Brazil. Our predictions outperformed traditional polls in both cases, demonstrating the global applicability of our approach. The Indian election results were closely aligned with our model’s forecasts, earning recognition from major news outlets,including Bloomberg and Analytics India Magazine.

Implications and Broader Impact

Our research has implications for the future of political forecasting and data-driven decision-making. By providing a more accurate and unbiased alternative to traditional polling, our AI-driven approach can enhance electoral transparency, improve campaign strategies, and offer valuable insights into voter behavior. Additionally, the commercialization of this technology opens new opportunities for media organizations, political consultants, and data analysts seeking reliable election forecasting tools. The need for our solution and the success of our methodology have been further reinforced by multiple letters of support received from various media and political consultancy groups, and hundreds of customer discovery interviews conducted at the Beat the Odds Bootcamps and I-Corps training program confirming the demand for an accurate and scalable election prediction system.

Beyond politics, our methodology has potential applications in market research, public policy analysis, and crisis response, where understanding public sentiment is crucial. Our work aligns with NSF’s mission of advancing scientific innovation for societal benefit, demonstrating the power of AI in addressing real-world challenges.

Conclusion

The outcomes of this project highlight the transformative potential of AI in political forecasting. By leveraging advanced machine learning techniques and social media data, we have developed a pioneering solution that addresses the shortcomings of traditional polling methods. As we move forward, our work will continue to shape the future of election forecasting, offering a more accurate, scalable, and data-driven approach to understanding voter sentiment on a global scale.
